title: SIMS analytical artefacts
text: combination measuring high ionisation efficiencies usage electron multipliers (EM) ion detection can lead artefact understood --less (quasi) simultaneous arrival (QSA) incident ion detection device. Differentiation two secondary ions thus possible, ions therefore counted \(1\) detection event machine. case isotope systems theoretically lead -sampling common isotope (Slodzian et al. 2004). exact correction -sampling induced QSA can cumbersome undertaking, R package point (Schobben 2022) diagnostic tool helps evaluate whether ion count data likely compromised analytical artefact. function QSA_test() fits least-square linear model common isotope count rates (e.g. 12C) predictor, targeted isotope ratio (e.g. 13C/12C) independent variable. -sampling present ion count data, cause significant positive linear trend higher isotope ratios higher count rates common isotope. function gg_dens provided package used visualise high density data. QSA test.
code: library(dplyr)  # combine data tb <- bind_rows(map_sum_grid_64_MEX, map_sum_grid_64_MON) # QSA test test_QSA_64_all <- QSA_test(tb, "13C", "12C", file.nm, sample.nm, grid.nm,                              .nest = grid.nm) # make mlm model line test_QSA_64_all <- mutate(   test_QSA_64_all,    hat_R = alpha_grid.nm + beta_grid.nm * Xt.pr.12C ) # labels for ion count rates xlab <- substitute(   a ~ "(count sec"^"-"*")",    list(a = point::ion_labeller("12C", "expr"))   ) ylab <- point::R_labeller("13C", "12C", "expr")  # plot QSA_dens <- gg_dens(   IC = test_QSA_64_all,    x = Xt.pr.12C,   y = R_Xt.pr,    xlab = xlab,    ylab = ylab,    ttl = "QSA test",   gr = sample.nm,   unit = "dim",   facet_sc = "free",   labels = "scientific" )  # add lm line QSA_dens + geom_line(aes(y = hat_R))   # save data write_point(test_QSA_64_all)   # save plot   save_point("point_QSA", last_plot(), width = 15, height = 10, unit = "cm")

title: SIMS analytical artefacts
text: random nature secondary ions emitted analytical substrate (e.g. rock sample) sputtering can described Poisson statistics, can used predict precision pulsed ion counts (e.g. measurements Cameca NanoSIMS 50L) ideal circumstances. specifically, variation can deduced total counts secondary ions. Usefully, can compare predictive values descriptive statistics; essentially estimates true population location (e.g. mean) spread (variance). First calculate standard predictive descriptive statistics internal precision SIMS single iona, point function stat_X(). See documentation package vignette("IC-precision", package = "point") extensive overview complete functionality functions well mathematics behind statistics. can done statistics isotope analysis appropriate error propagation function stat_R(). reduced \(\chi^2\) can used assess machine performance analyte homogeneity cross-validates observed error estimate theoretical Poisson-based precision. example, reduced \(\chi^2\) isotope ratio equates : \[\begin{equation}   \chi^2 = \left( \frac{s_{\bar{R}}} {\hat{s}_{\bar{R}}} \right)^2    \end{equation}\] values close \(1\) suggest good agreement actual measurement predicted value (Kilburn Wacey 2015). Values lower \(1\) suggest analysis better predicted, values higher \(1\) indicate analysis worse predicted Poisson statistics. Intra-analysis isotope variation measured test (based F-statistic) outlined paper. Varying degrees variance ionization efficiency analyte cause systematic trend mirrored isotopes. ionization efficiency trend parameterized difference relative standard deviation common isotope \(\epsilon_{X^{}}\) theoretical standard deviation \(\hat{\epsilon}_{N^{}}\), based Poisson statistics (-called “excess” ionization, see paper). ionization efficiency trend impact accuracy intra-analysis isotope test (see paper), therefore included simulated data. comparative approach excess ionization < 6% omitted, limited detection lower ranges ionization efficiency. remainder divided three groups; low (5–15%), medium (15–25%) high (25–35%) excess ionization ggplot2::cut_width() function (Wickham et al. 2021; Wickham 2016). simple ggplot (ggplot() + geom_point()) (Wickham et al. 2021; Wickham 2016) used compare \(F\) statistic intra-analysis isotope variability reduced \(\chi^2\) assessment precision. sensitivity precision accuracy-based test statistics intra-isotope variability.
code: # single ion statistics stat_X_64_all <- stat_X(tb, file.nm, sample.nm, dim_name.nm, grid.nm) write_point(stat_X_64_all) head(stat_X_64_all) # single ion statistics stat_R_64_all <- stat_R(tb, "13C", "12C", file.nm, sample.nm, dim_name.nm,                          grid.nm) write_point(stat_R_64_all) head(stat_R_64_all) library(purrr) library(rlang) library(ggplot2)  # groups grps <- quos(type.nm, trend.nm, force.nm, spot.nm) # R stats synthetic data tb_R <- stat_R(simu_sens_IC_intra, "13C", "12C", !!!grps, .X = Xt.sm, .N = N.sm)  # single ions stats tb_X <- stat_X(simu_sens_IC_intra, !!!grps, .X = Xt.sm, .N = N.sm) |>    filter(species.nm == "12C") # filter and cut continuous ionization efficiency simu_stat_eval_intra <- list(simu_CooksD_IC_intra, tb_X, tb_R) %>%    reduce(left_join, by = sapply(grps, as_name)) %>%    mutate(ion_trend = RS_Xt.sm - hat_RS_N.sm) %>%    filter(ion_trend > 6) %>%    mutate(     ion_trend =       factor(cut_width(ion_trend, 10), labels = c("low", "medium", "high"))   ) # plot F vs Chi2 ggplot(   data = simu_stat_eval_intra,    mapping = aes(x = chi2_R_N.sm, y = F_R_Xt.sm, color = force.nm) ) +   geom_point() +   facet_grid(cols = vars(type.nm), rows = vars(ion_trend)) +   scale_color_distiller(     expression("isotope variation in substrate ("* Delta[B - A] *" \u2030 )"),     palette = "YlOrRd"   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     expression(F["(2),(n-3)"]),     expand = c(0, 0),     breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(4),   ) +   scale_x_continuous(     expression(chi^2),     expand = c(0, 0),     breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(4),   ) +   ggtitle("Precision vs. accuracy") +   themes_IC(base = theme_bw())   # save  save_point("simu_precision", last_plot(), width = 14, height = 14, unit = "cm")

title: Reading matlab files

what: The two “real” datasets of Schobben, Kienhuis and Polerecky 2021
title: Reading matlab files
text: two “real” ion mapping datasets (opposed simulated data) included external data (inst/extdata directory) package pointapply, pathways can conveniently generated function get_matlab(). Matlab files generated nanoSIMS imaging software Look@NanoSIMS (Polerecky et al. 2012). program contains algorithms alignment pixels across successive depth, depth-frames, ion mapping protocol. matlab-generated files contain multidimensional hyper-arrays (‘data cubes’), ion count measurements three spatial coordinates; width 256 pixels, height 256 pixels 400 frames depth, can gave several bandwidths, represent different chemical species analysed nanoSIMS. R.matlab (Bengtsson 2018) readmat (???) can used load Matlab files, latter fastest method relies full Matlab installation thus Matlab license. grid_aggregate function designed aggregate specified dimension (e.g. "height" see example ) set species (e.g. c("12C", "13C") see example ). grid-cell size aggregation can set grid_cell argument, integer exponent base two (64 pixels 64 pixels example). tibble contains following variables: sample.nm: sample name, provided title argument function. file.nm: original file name. grid_size.nm: Convert pixels grid-cell size (e.g. \(\mu\)m) dimensions, arguments scaler defaults 0.16\(\,\mu\)m pixel-. grid.nm: Grid-cell number. dim.nm: step value dimensional scale aggregation pixels (plane = height plane = width) depth-frames (plane = depth). * dim_name.nm: name dimensional scale aggregation (e.g. height). species.nm: chemical species name. N.rw: ion counts. t.nm: time increments (seconds), based \(1\,\)millisecond per pixel.
code: get_matlab("2020-08-20-GLENDON") # MEX # the files MEX_files <- list.files(get_matlab("2020-08-20-GLENDON"), full.names = TRUE) MON_files <- list.files(get_matlab("2020-08-28-GLENDON"), full.names = TRUE) # read files (alternatively use R.matlab) MEX <- lapply(MEX_files, readmat::read_mat)  MON <- lapply(MON_files, readmat::read_mat) # get measured species names MEX_species <- vapply(MEX, attr, character(1), "file") MON_species <- vapply(MEX, attr, character(1), "file") MEX_species <- gsub("_cnt", "", MEX_species) MON_species <- gsub("_cnt", "", MON_species) # set names MEX <- unlist(MEX, recursive = FALSE) |>  stats::setNames(MEX_species) MON <- unlist(MON, recursive = FALSE) |>  stats::setNames(MON_species) grid_aggregate(MEX, "height", 64, c("12C", "13C"))
